user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_register_generic:
```c
int metal_shmem_register_generic(struct metal_generic_shmem *shmem)
{
	/* Make sure that we can be found. */
	metal_assert(shmem->name && strlen(shmem->name) != 0);

	/* Statically registered shmem regions cannot have a destructor. */
	metal_assert(!shmem->io.ops.close);

	metal_list_add_tail(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list,
			    &shmem->node);
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_shmem_register_generic:
#define metal_assert(cond) metal_sys_assert(cond)
...
struct metal_generic_shmem {
	const char		*name;
	struct metal_io_region	io;
	struct metal_list	node;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_assert(shmem->name && strlen(shmem->name) != 0);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the call to metal_assert(shmem->name && strlen(shmem->name) != 0) is an executed runtime check that can change program behaviour (e.g. abort, log, report) when the condition fails. Removing it could change observable behaviour on failure, so it is not dead code. (If, however, metal_sys_assert is implemented as a guaranteed no-op in all builds, then the check would be dead; based on the provided definition it maps to metal_sys_assert, so we cannot assume that.)
